Stochastic Approximation Approach to Federated Machine Learning*

Srihari P V1 ‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ Bharath Bhikkaji2 *This work was not supported by any organization1Srihari P V is a MS student at the Department of Electrical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Madras, India. sriharivenkat95@gmail.com2Bharath Bhikkaji is a faculty with the Department of Electrical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Madras, India. bharath.bhikkaji@iitm.ac.in
Abstract

This paper examines Federated learning (FL) in a Stochastic Approximation (SA) framework. FL is a collaborative way to train neural network models across various participants or clients without centralizing their data. Each client will train a model on their respective data and send the weights across to a the server periodically for aggregation. The server aggregates these weights which are then used by the clients to re-initialize their neural network and continue the training. SA is an iterative algorithm that uses approximate sample gradients and tapering step size to locate a minimizer of a cost function. In this paper the clients use a stochastic approximation iterate to update the weights of its neural network. It is shown that the aggregated weights track an autonomous ODE. Numerical simulations are performed and the results are compared with standard algorithms like FedAvg and FedProx. It is observed that the proposed algorithm is robust and gives more reliable estimates of the weights, in particular when the clients data are not identically distributed.

Index Terms:
Federated learning, Stochastic Approximation, Autonomous ODE.

I Introduction

Federated learning (FL) is a machine learning framework introduced to collaboratively train and build robust machine learning models across various users while maintaining their data privacy [1],[2],[3]. FL enables collaborative / collective model training (model jointly owned by all the participants) while keeping the data localized in their respective centers (without having to share with other particpants). FL framework has been applied in health care for tasks like MRI analysis of the brain and tumor detection from medical images [4]. It has also been applied for analyzing Electronic health records (EHR) to identify disease patterns, predicting hospitalization risks etc., while preserving the data privacy of the patients [4]. In the banking sector FL is utilized to predict the loan repayment ability or the credit score of the customers without violating their data privacy [5].

A underlying abstraction of the federated learning framework consists of LùêøL local clients (ùíû1,ùíû2,‚Ä¶,ùíûLsubscriptùíû1subscriptùíû2‚Ä¶subscriptùíûùêø\mathcal{C}_{1},\mathcal{C}_{2},\ldots,\mathcal{C}_{L}) and a server ùíÆùíÆ\mathcal{S}. The clients possess their own datasets {D1,D2,‚ãØ,DL}subscriptùê∑1subscriptùê∑2‚ãØsubscriptùê∑ùêø\{D_{1},D_{2},\cdots,D_{L}\}. These datasets are assumed to be independent and follow a specific distribution Œæ(i)superscriptùúâùëñ\xi^{(i)} for each client iùëñi. The distributions need not be identical. Each client runs a Neural Network (NN). The NN architecture adopted by the clients are assumed to be the identical i.e., the number of layers, number of neurons per layer and the activation functions in each layer of the NN are assumed to be the same. The weight update mechanism for these NNs are given by

(6)

where wn(i)subscriptsuperscriptùë§ùëñùëõw^{(i)}_{n} is the weight of the neural network for client iùëñi at time step or instant nùëõn, an>0subscriptùëéùëõ0a_{n}>0 is the step size, fùëìf is a twice differentiable cost function, Œæ(i)superscriptùúâùëñ\xi^{(i)} the data distribution for client iùëñi and NùëÅN is an integer greater than or equal to 2.

In words, (6) implies each client individually trains its NN and updates its weights at all instants nùëõn, except when nùëõn is a multiple of NùëÅN. At these instants the server aggregates the weights of all clients. The individual client NNs weights are then reinitialized to this aggregated weight and iterations of the clients continue until the next multiple of NùëÅN. This process is repeated indefinitely. If m=1ùëö1m=1 then the iterates, (6), become a stochastic gradient updates. If mùëöm is greater than one but much lesser than the size of the dataset then the iterates are referred to as mini-batch gradient updates.

Stochastic approximation (SA) algorithms are search algorithms to find the optima of a performance criteria [6] [7] . It is widely used when the performance updates have to be made in a random or uncertain environments (stochastic environment). The updates are typically based on the responses from the stochastic environment. SA algorithms are computationally simple and less fluctuating when compared with other search algorithms. This paper analyses the convergence of the mini-batch gradient method in a stochastic approximation frame-work.

Note that, replacing the expectation in (6) by (7) leads to

Related Works & Contribution

A very well cited early work on FL is [2]. Therein two algorithms referred to as Federated Stochastic Gradient Descent (FedSGD) and Federated Averaging (FedAvg) were proposed. In the more basic FedSGD the sample gradient in (6) was substituted with a mini batch gradient (7) and the number of local updates NùëÅN was set to 111 (N=1ùëÅ1N=1). The step size was taken to be a constant an=Œ∑>0,‚àÄnformulae-sequencesubscriptùëéùëõùúÇ0for-allùëõa_{n}=\eta>0,\forall\ n. In FedAvg, N>1ùëÅ1N>1 and a variable number of client participation was allowed. That is a subset of the clients were chosen and then averaged . The weights of the chosen clients were then replaced by averaged weights. The performance of the FedSGD and FedAvg algorithms were empirically validated on benchmark datasets [2]. An improvement to FedAvg is FedProx [8]. Therein a proximal term, Œº2‚Äã‚Äñw‚àíwn(i)‚Äñ2ùúá2superscriptnormùë§subscriptsuperscriptùë§ùëñùëõ2\frac{\mu}{2}\parallel w-w^{(i)}_{n}\parallel^{2}, that served as a regularizer was added to the client updates in (6), where wùë§w denoted the last or the most recent averaged weight and Œºùúá\mu a scalar. This modification made the algorithm more amenable for theoretical analysis and enabled robust convergence on datasets. Nevertheless convergence analysis performed on FedProx required a nonzero proximal term. The proofs do not apply for FedAvg (when this term is absent). Another modification referred to as FedNova was presented in [9]. FedNova normalises the gradient updates in FedAvg and FedProx. The normalization term compensated for both the number of local updates (for a given NùëÅN) and also the magnitude of the gradient. Convergence was proved for ‚Äùarbitrarily small‚Äù values of step sizes. That is the step sizes had to converge to zero.

There have been other alternatives, where in the weights wn(i)subscriptsuperscriptùë§ùëñùëõw^{(i)}_{n} sent for averaging by the clients were permuted and then averaged, [10] and [11]. Alternatively stated, the weights w(i)superscriptùë§ùëñw^{(i)} were first multiplied by a permutation matrix œÄ(i)superscriptùúãùëñ\pi^{(i)} and the resulting œÄ(i)‚Äãwn(i)superscriptùúãùëñsubscriptsuperscriptùë§ùëñùëõ\pi^{(i)}w^{(i)}_{n} were averaged. The choice of œÄ(i)superscriptùúãùëñ\pi^{(i)}‚Äôs depended on the pattern of correlation among the weights. In [12] each client was selected with a certain probability and their weights were averaged. In all the above mentioned references the convergence of the algorithms were numerically validated.

This paper provides a stochastic approximation frame work for the Federated learning problem. Under certain assumptions the updates (13) are shown to converge, with probability 111, to the local minimizer of the averaged cost function. If the cost functions for the individual clients are convex then the iterates will converge to the global minimizer of the averaged cost function.

The contributions of this paper are :

  1. 1.

    A Stochastic approximation frame work has been applied to the Federated learning problem (to the best of author‚Äôs knowledge for the first time).

  2. 2.

    In this framework the iterates are shown to track the solution of an autonomous ODE with the governing function being the average or mean of the cost functions of individual clients.

  3. 3.

    In cases where ODE is asymptotically stable, the iterates converge to the equilibrium point of the tracked ODE which are the local minimizers.

  4. 4.

    Numerical simulations suggesting good convergence properties for both identically and non-identically distributed cases are presented.

This paper is organized as follows: The underlying assumptions for convergence analysis is provided in Section¬†II. In Section¬†III, the consequence of the assumptions are summarized. In Section¬†IV, the convergence analysis is performed. The experimental results are presented in Section¬†V. The paper concludes in Section¬†VI.

V Simulations

This section presents simulations validating the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm (13). The performance of the algorithm is compared with that of FedAvg and FedProx.

V-A Simulation Platform

The federated learning simulations with 111 server and LùêøL clients are performed on a 13th gen intel i9 processor equipped with a 64GB DDR4 RAM. A 48GB RTX6000 graphics card is used for accelerating the training of the neural network models. The code base for the federated learning setup is developed in Python utilizing the Flower framework [14]. For consistency and reproducibility all the experiments are performed with the same seed value for the random number generator.

V-B Datasets and Models

Widely recognized labelled benchmark datasets like F-MNIST [15], CIFAR-10 [16], CIFAR-100 [16] and STL-10 [17] are chosen for the simulation. The F-MNIST dataset consists of 70,0007000070,000 grey-scale images, each having a dimension of 28√ó28282828\times 28 pixels. The images are from 10 classes with 6000 images per class for training and 1,000 images per class for testing. The CIFAR-10 dataset comprises of 60,000 32x32 color images across 10 classes with 6000 images per class in which 50000 are training images and 10000 are test images. The CIFAR-100 dataset is similar to CIFAR-10 in terms of image counts and size but consists of 100 classes with 600 images per class. The STL-10 dataset is inspired from CIFAR-10 dataset but consists of 13,000 96 x96 pixels sized images with 1,300 images per class.

LeNet-5 an early successful model for hand written character recognition is used for training F-MNIST. The model consists of 3 Convolutional layers followed 2 fully connected layers, with a pooling (sub-sampling) layer between the Convolutional layers . The remaining datasets are trained using a Resnet-9 architecture composed of total 3 convolutional layers, 2 Residual layer, a pooling layer and one linear layer. For more details on the architecture refer to [18] and [19].

V-C Dataset partitioning Strategies

The dataset partitioning strategies define how the training data is distributed over the clients. The following three data partitioning strategies are considered on the above mentioned datasets. The first method (IID) is the Independent and Identical split of data where equal portions of the data is randomly sampled from the training set and assigned to each client. In this split, the data distribution across the client‚Äôs are similar. In the second strategy (DIR) the training data for each client is allocated according to Dirichlet distribution (D‚Äãi‚Äãr‚Äã(Œ±)ùê∑ùëñùëüùõºDir(\alpha)) [20]. In this split varying proportions of data from each class is allocated to the clients. This partitioning simulates a non-identical data distribution across clients. The third technique (SC-DIR) is the recent approach for creating real world non-identical data distributions among the client. In this method, the training data is segregated into multiple disjoint subsets called Super clusters [21]. Each subset contains data pertaining to some class. Due to the disjoint nature of the subset no two super clusters have overlapping classes. The clients are allowed data only from one of the many super clusters and the allocation of the data is again based on a Dirichlet distribution mentioned in the second method.

V-D Implementation Details

All the experiments are carried out with L=10ùêø10L=10 clients. Each client performs N=5ùëÅ5N=5 local epochs before sending the model to the server for aggregation. A total of 100 federated rounds are performed on each dataset. The mini-batch size of m=16ùëö16m=16 is fixed for all the experiments. The clients minimize a Cross Entropy loss function using a SGD optimizer with no momentum. Two Stochastic approximation algorithms are presented, one with step size an=0.1nsubscriptùëéùëõ0.1ùëõa_{n}=\frac{0.1}{n} and another with step size an=0.1‚åänN‚åã+1subscriptùëéùëõ0.1ùëõùëÅ1a_{n}=\frac{0.1}{\lfloor{\frac{n}{N}}\rfloor+1}. The former is called the Stochastic each epoch algorithm while the later is called the Stochastic algorithm in the figures. The other algorithms have a constant learning rate of Œ∑=0.1ùúÇ0.1\eta=0.1. For FedProx Œºùúá\mu is chosen to be 0.25. Note, for an exact comparison between the algorithms the learning rate is not decayed in FedAvg and FedProx. The aggregated model is validated on the test sets. The results for the algorithms are presented in Fig¬†2 and Fig¬†3.

V-E Observations

From Fig¬†2 and Fig¬†3 for IID split, it is apparent that the proposed algorithm achieves the same level of accuracy as the other algorithms while having a lower test loss. This shows that the proposed algorithms learns the features of the data better than its counterparts. In DIR and SC-DIR splits, the algorithm achieves a similar level of accuracy at a better loss values comparable to that of the other algorithms. Also the proposed method exhibits a notable stability in its performance across the rounds. This consistency in accuracy and loss, suggests that the proposed algorithm is robust in its learning process and has better convergence behaviour when the data across the clients are distributed in a Non-identical fashion.

VI Conclusion

This paper presented a Federated learning problem in the Stochastic Approximation frame work. In this frame work it is first shown that the iterates of the global model track the solution of an autonomous ODE. Since the autonomous ODE is asymptotically stable, the iterates converge to an equilibrium point which is a local minimizer. Numerical simulations were performed and the results were compared with benchmark algorithms like FedAvg and FedProx. The comparison reveals that the proposed method is more robust and converges to local minima without much oscillations. The future work will be to come up with a convergence rate for the proposed algorithm and also to analyse the presented algorithm with varying step size i.e an(i)‚â†an(j)subscriptsuperscriptùëéùëñùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùëéùëóùëõa^{(i)}_{n}\neq a^{(j)}_{n} for two different clients iùëñi and jùëój.
